intro: Willoughbya sarcodes, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a striking member of the Araceae family native to the tropical rainforests of Queensland, Australia. It is characterized by its large, showy inflorescence, which consists of a spadix surrounded by a colorful spathe. The plant produces small, green berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Willoughbya sarcodes thrives in humid, shaded environments and requires consistent moisture. Its unique appearance and ecological significance make it a notable species in botanical studies.
